links.title: Longitudinal analysis shows durable and broad immune memory after SARS-CoV-2 infection with persisting antibody responses and memory B and T cells
links.description:
Cohen et al. evaluate immune responses longitudinally in 254 COVID-19 patients over
8 months. SARS-CoV-2-specific binding and neutralizing antibodies exhibit biphasic
decay, suggesting long-lived plasma cell generation. Memory B cells remain stable;
CD4 and CD8 memory T cells are polyfunctional. Thus, broad and effective immunity
may persist long-term following COVID-19.

to vaccination have not been well-studied. In a longitudinal cohort, Painter, Matthew
et al. show that mRNA vaccines activate SARS-CoV-2-specific T cells that could contribute
to durable immunity. The findings highlight the central role of T cells in the two-dose
vaccine regimen for individuals not previously infected with SARS-CoV-2.

links.description:

Scientists at Brisbane's Nucleus Network believe that the treatment could be more effective against the virus than the AstraZeneca and Pfizer drugs and that it would allow patients who are afraid of needles to be inoculated.
